question: When?
You okay?
answer: Mmm, mm. Yeah. How was the show?

question: Mmmh. Trouble sleeping?
You're sure?
Burning the midnight oil?
Okay.
Well, the month's up. I think we should stick to the plan.
answer: The plan was if I needed to call him.

question: Yeah. Okay. Don't worry about it. Get some sleep. By the way, I am working on those Michigan State tickets.
What about the Warrens, did you call them?
answer: Yeah, they said they'll make it some evening soon. "Joey Georgella. New football coach for Trinity." Did you check with Jane for the Michigan State tickets?

question: Yes. She'll talk to John. Where's Conrad? This'll get cold.
answer: Con! Will you drop those suits at the cleaners for me?

question: They won't be back by Saturday.
Morning.
Yeah.
Breakfast, pal, remember? Main meal. Energy!
answer: You're not hungry, you're not hungry!

question: Wait a minute, Beth, Hang on. He's gonna eat it. Come on. It's French toast.
answer: There's fresh fruit for you when you get home from school later.

question: What are you doing? What are you doing?
You have to charm Mr. Herman. Did you charm him? You have to eat, Con. We just want you keep on getting stronger.
Are you okay?
answer: Yeah. I got to go. Lazenby's picking me up.

question: Oh. Is he? Great!
Well. I don't see the old gang much anymore. I miss them. Bring them around... Phil, Don, and Dick Van Buren. We'll play some touch football on the lawn.
Stillman, you know they don't pass you on... breathing in that dump if you don't take the final.
answer: Hey, man, get something on that radio, really. You know, I gotta study.

question: We're going to be late.
Uh... I don't... Uh...Powerless? I guess he thought he was, yeah. Hello.
Uh, Dr. Berger?
Hi. This is Conrad Jarrett calling.
Conrad Jarrett! Dr. Crawford at Hillsboro Hospital gave me your number... and...
answer: Oh, yes! I'm with a patient now. Can you call back at two fifteen?

question: I don't think I'll be free.
answer: Then give me your number. I'll call you tonite. Hello? Hello?

question: Was he actually a client of yours?
It's too bad.
answer: I mean.. it's tragic. Really. Look at him now. He's lost everything.

question: Fish too dry?
They have a new mechanic at C&S.
I don't know. I think he took a job in Skokie. Anyway, this new mechanic is so ...awkward. Is that shirt ripped? Leave it on the table in the hallway.
answer: That girl from the hospital, the one you painted with, she was from Skokie, wasn't she?

question: That girl from the hospital, the one you painted with, she was from Skokie, wasn't she?
What was her name?
Sharon?
Bucky! Fuck! Fuck! Ha... Oh, hi. How are you? /.../ Oh. I'm fine /.../ Couldn't be better, really. Oh, terrific, yeah.
answer: Ha! Hi! Come in. It's OK, they all do that.

question: Not yet.
answer: Hmm.... Jarrett. How long since you've been out of the hospital?

question: A month and a half.
No.
Pardon me?
answer: People nervous... treating you like you're ...a dangerous character?

question: Yeah. I guess a little.
I don't know.
answer: How long were you in the hospital?

question: Four months.
I tried to off myself. Isn't it down there?
answer: It doesn't say what your method was.

question: Double-edged Super Blue.
Yeah.
Yeah.
Yeah.
Yeah.
answer: You're back in school? Everything okay at school? Teachers?

question: Yeah.
Uh-uh.
Uh... I'd like to be more in control, I guess.
So people can quit worrying about me.
My father, mostly. This is his idea.
answer: What about your mother? Isn't she worried about you, too?

question: I don't know, listen. You... You're a friend of Dr Crawford, so you're probably all right, but I'll be straight with you, I don't like this already.
answer: Well, as long as you're straight.

question: What do you know about me? Have you talked to Crawford?
answer: Yes. He called me on the phone. He told me your name and... he told me to look for you. And, uh... he said you had a brother who died. A... boating accident, wasn't it? Want to tell me about it?

question: Right.
It didn't change anything.
answer: Why do you want to change?

question: I told you, I'd like to be more in control.
I told you, so people can quit worrying about me.
answer: Well. I'll tell you something. I'll be straight with you, okay? I'm not big on control. But it's your money.

question: So to speak.
Twice... a week?
I've got swim practice every night.
answer: Well. That's a problem. How do we solve that?

question: Guess I'll have to skip practice twice a week, and come here.
I don't like being here. I got to tell you I don't like being here at all.
I saw Mort Swain. His sister died.
The one with the restaurant.
I guess so. Why?
answer: You said she was always traveling. I just... wondered if she died in Idaho.

question: I don't know. Maybe she died in Idaho. Maybe Kansas City.
answer: I went to see Dr. Berger.

question: Berger?
Did you?
Good! You didn't say anything. Good!
When?
How did it go?
answer: If it's too much money, I don't have to go. It's not necessary...

question: Don't worry about the money, it's okay.
answer: Well it's 50 $ an hour. Twice a week.

question: Ah, it's okay. And it is necessary. What did you talk about?
What about your schedule? Will that be all right?
answer: Well, it'll cut into swim practice.

question: Highland Park.
answer: Keep that head straight Genthe! I don't want to tell you again!

question: Yeah.
answer: Well, are you having fun out there?

question: Fun?
answer: There's no point if you're not having fun. Right?

question: Yeah. I guess so.
answer: You guess so...? Are you on medication, Jarrett? Tranquilizers? Anything?

question: No. No, sir.
answer: Did I ask you if they gave you shock out there?

question: Yeah.
Yeah. You asked me. Yeah, they did.
answer: Don't look at us, Lazenby! Get your ass in the water! Look at the bottom of the pool! You know, I'm no doctor, Jarrett. I would never have let them put electricity in my head.

question: You, you stand behind me in the choir.
answer: Oh? I do? You do? Is that you?

question: You have a lot of energy.
Yeah. I mean, That's good. My name's Jeannine Pratt.
answer: Nice. Hi! Right. Hum. Yeah. Um. Bye.

question: You're the scariest ghost I've ever seen! And the tiger and the witch... You all look just wonderful. Take an apple. There you go. Be careful. Good-bye. Know what I've been thinking?
That Christmas in London would be like something out of Dickens. We've never done that before, right? Christmas in London?
answer: Maybe we shouldn't plan to go away right now.

question: Yes, we talked about that. We decided on that.
answer: Yeah. I know we talked about it, but the more I talk about it, the more the timing doesn't seem right.

question: Calvin, we've always gone away at Christmas time.
I think... I think it would be good for him too. Isn't it time we got back to normal?
answer: He's just started with this doctor.

question: Alright, so he'll miss three weeks. Why interrupt it?
answer: No. If he doesn't go through with this now, he might change his mind.

question: Alright then if he changes his mind, maybe it's not something that was right for him to do.
answer: You talked to him about it? Does he want to go to London?

question: I don't think he knows what he wants to do. HA!
Don't do that!
Ha. I didn't think you were here
answer: I'm sorry, I just got in. I didn't... I didn't know you were here.

question: I didn't play golf, today. It's too cold.
I didn't play.
answer: Oh... It did get colder today.

question: No, I mean, ...for the year it's colder.
Weren't you swimming today?
How'd it go?
Good.
answer: Yeah. Personaly I think I could swim the 50 if my timing got...

question: Off.
answer: ...my timing got better. I'm a just a little... a little off with my... my timing.

question: Well, you have to work at that.
answer: Yeah. Oh, I got seventy four on a trig quiz.

question: Seventy four? Gee, I was awful at trig.
answer: Oh? Did you...? You took Trig?

question: Wait a minute... Did I take trig? That's... - uh...? I bought you two shirts. They're on your bed.
Well. The Murrays of course, and the Gunthers, and the Caines, and... the good old us.
answer: Why don't we just go to the movies instead?

question: Don't be negative.
answer: That's not negative. That's unpredictable. Come on. Let's really go to the movies.

question: Okay.
Okay. Yeah. Come on. Let's go. What's our excuse?
answer: Beth wanted to go to the movies?

question: Good. Very good. All right now, smile. Hello Gladyce. Will you put that with the rest of them? Clark! Happy birthday! You look wonderful for a 75-year-old! You did the mousse? It turned out well?

Hi there. Good to see you, and where were you at the lunch last week? Your hair looks wonderful. It's shorter, isn't it? I like that. Good to see you! You look beautiful. As ever. What are these hushed tones all about?
answer: Why? Where is he going? Jesus.

question: No. You didn't. You're so mean. Isn't he the meanest man you've met?
answer: Hi. Annie. What's your boy up to these days? He's great. Just great. Oh! Oh, no, no. Nothing like that. No, no, just somebody to talk to... that's all. Kind of polish off the rough edges, that's all.

question: How are you. Darling? Is he falling asleep on you, yet?
You drink too much at parties, Calvin.
Why did you tell Annie Marshall that Conrad is seeing a psychiatrist?
Well for one thing, I don't think people hear that kind of thing very easily.
answer: Come on, for most people, it's a status symbol, right up there with going to Europe.

question: Well, I thought your blurting it out like that was in very bad taste...
answer: I did not think it was that...

question: Not to mention a violation of privacy!
So what do I do... tell you my dreams?
answer: I don't hold much stock in dreams.

question: What kind of a psychiatrist are you? They all believe in dreams.
answer: Really? What's happening? What's going on?

question: I just feel... I feel so...
Jumpy. I don't know.
answer: Look. Kiddo... I lied. I do believe in dreams. Only sometimes I want to know what's happening when you're awake. Come on, something's bugging you, making you nervous. You're making me nervous.

question: Maybe I need a tranquilizer.
Yeah.
answer: I think you came in here looking like something out of The Body Snatchers. It's not my impression that you need a tranquilizer.

question: What is this?
Oh, I see. So you get to tell the time, but I can't. Is that it?
So you know when the hour's up?
Fifty minutes, fifty five minutes? What is it?
They're a bunch of boring ass jocks.
And him... I can't stand him. He's a tight ass son of a bitch!
answer: Ah, ah?... Have you ever thought about quitting?

question: Are you telling me to?
It wouldn't look good.
answer: Forget about how it looks! How does it feel?

question: How does it feel? How does it feel?
How does it feel?!
It's the same thing that happened last year... It's the same damn thing I did last year.
answer: Are you the same person you were last year?

question: I don't know!
answer: That's why you need a tranquilizer?

question: You tell me!
Fifty bucks an hour, can't you decide if I should have a pill or not? I mean, you're a doctor, I'm supposed to feel better! Right?
No. It's still hard.
The hospital was.
Because nobody hid anything there.
answer: Was there anyone there you could talk to?

question: Uh-huh.
Uh-huh. Whoa!
Hey, Karen! Hi! How are you?
Sit down. Please.
Wow.
Uh... The end of August.
It's great to see you.
answer: Oh, you too. Listen. I am not gonna be able to stay a real long time. I've got a meeting over at school. Drama Club meeting. We're doing "A Thousand Clowns" this year. You know it? Anyway. We're going so crazy trying to get it together. I am secretary this year too.

question: Don't let me hang you up.
answer: No. Oh, no, you're not hanging me up! No, I really wanted to see you. I didn't know quite what to expect, though... I mean, you sounded...uh, you sounded sort of funny on the phone.

question: No, no, I wasn't. It was just a gray day, that's all. Kind of... But everything's great, I'm back in school, I am on the swim team, and...
answer: Oh. You're swimming? Terrific, Conrad! That's... That's really wonderful.

question: We haven't had any meets yet. I could end up on the bench all year, but...
answer: Come on, you'll do great. I'll bet your folks are real proud of you.

question: Yeah, yeah. You're hungry, at all?
answer: Uh... I just want a coke.

question: Uh... two cokes, please.
Something I said? Definitely a low self-image day.
You really look beautiful.
Do you miss it?
The hospital.
You don't miss it? At all? Nothing? Nothing about it?
You don't miss Leo's corny jokes?
Yeah. I'm seeing a doctor. Are you?
answer: Uh... Uh, well, Dr. Crawford gave me a name, and I went for a while. But uh... I dunno.It just didn't work for me, I guess. He just kept telling me all the things I already knew, and , uh... finally, I decided... the only one who can help me is myself. At least, that's what my dad says. I don't mean it's not right for you, Conrad. I mean I think that if it's something you want to do, that's what you should be doing.

question: Well, ya, I don't know how long I'll keep it up. I sorta got shoved into it.
Oh, yes. That was such a dumb thing to do.
You do?
I don't know, I just... Uh... I miss it sometimes, the hospital. Really do.
answer: Things have to change. You know?

question: But that's where we had the laughs.
answer: But that was a hospital. This is the real world.

question: Yeah, yeah, I... you're sure right.
answer: I really have to go. I'm sorry. I have a meeting over at the school. Drama Club meeting. We're doing "A Thousand Clowns".

question: I know, you told me.
Yeah.
answer: I better hurry. Don't wanna be late.

question: Thanks for seeing me.
answer: Conrad? Let's have a great Christmas! Okay? Let's have... a great year. Let's have the best year of our whole lives, OK? We can, you know. This could be the best year ever.

question: Yeah... Yeah.
Yeah...
Yep!
answer: You. Uh... You look good. Conrad.

question: Yeah.
Bye-bye.
It's cold out here. You should put that on, or do you want a sweater?
What are you doing?
About what?
Your hair is starting to grow out. It's looking... looking better.
answer: I was thinking about the pigeon... You know the one that used to hang around the garage. How it used to get on top of your car, and he take off when you pulled out of the driveway.

question: Oh. Yeah, I remember. I remember how scared I used to get... That whosssshhhhh! Flap, flap, flap, flap!... Every time I started the car.
answer: Yeah. That was the closest we ever came to having a pet. You remember Buck asked you, he tried to talk you into... getting a dog. Do you remember that? He said. "How about it, if it's the size of a little football?"

question: You know. Uh... That animal next door, that Pepper or Pippin, whatever its name is...
He's not a very friendly dog... I... I don't care what Mr. McGreary says.
Put that on if you're gonna stay out here, okay?
Help what? Oh, you mean with this? No.
No, I tell you what you can do though. You can go upstairs to that room of yours and clean out the closet.
What do you expect from her?
Why not?
answer: I don't know. We just don't.

question: What are you thinking?
answer: That I jack off a lot.

question: So what else is new? Does it help?
What now?
Who?
answer: You know, in "The Waltons". John Boy?

question: Yeah. What about him?
answer: My father came into my room and he didn't know what to say. This is right after Buck died. And he came over and sat on the bed next to me, put his arm around my shoulder. We just sat there. I remember I was watching his shoe. And thinking... Cos his shoe was turned over on its side. I was thinking

question: So much as what?
answer: I dunno. I kept thinking that John Boy would've said something...about the way he felt, you know. Something.

question: What would John Boy have said?
Come on.
Well. At least she's an improvement. She doesn't crack gum in your face. That's what you get when your partner does the hiring and firing.
answer: Oh, I'm sorry. That's my fault. I just can never seem to tell anybody that they're not making it.

question: Hold, hold it. Wait a minute. That's not the problem. Where are you?
I've been losing you these days.
That's okay. That's okay. You off the track?
Come on. I've known you for twenty years. You think I can't tell when something's wrong? How's Connie?
answer: Connie's all right. He is. He's okay.

question: Look, I am sorry, it's none of my business, but I think you worry too much. You've been on the rack about him long enough. You're making it a habit. You've gotta let him go sometime.
answer: I'm not on the rack about him.

question: The thing about it is, in a year he'll be gone. Off to Michigan or Harvard or wherever in the hell he gets it in his head he wants to go. Maybe he'll decide to take a tour of Europe for a year and not even go to school at all. Who knows?
I'm just try giving you the benefit of my experience.

With Valerie, it's more than her living away from home... She's gone. Got her own friends, her own life. She breezes in ...for a couple of days on vacations, but... I don't know, maybe girls are different. Or maybe she was too aware of what was happening between Nance and me. But they leave... And all that worrying doesn't amount to a hill of crap. It's just wasted energy.
answer: Hang on! Wait, hang on! Whose sweater is it? That's fair! Conrad! Conrad!

question: What it is you want? I don't know what else to do for you.
answer: I'm not asking you for anything.

question: You gotta be kidding me. I don't get it. I excuse you from practice twice a week so you can see some shrink. I work with you every damn night at your convenience. What the hell more am I supposed to do for you?
Bright kid like you, everything going for you. See, I don't get it. Why do you wanna keep messing up your life?
answer: I don't think that ...that quitting swimming will mess up my life. I... I really don't.

question: Okay. Okay. Now, this is it.
You're a big kid now.
Actions have consequences.
I'm not taking you back again. You'll remember that?
I won't ask you to ...sir.
Yeah.
answer: Salan says you quit the swim team.

question: Yeah.
I don't know. I felt like it was a bore.
Well, that's the way it is.
Nothing.
Nothing.
answer: Connie, come on, talk to me.

question: Nothing. Swimming's a bore. That's all.
answer: Well listen, I talked to Salan...

question: Well, quit talking to people! Okay?
answer: Holy shit! Yeah. Sure. Fuck you. Jarrett.

question: So, what did your dad say about it?
How come?
answer: I don't know. The timing isn't right, you know. He sweats everything so much, he'll just get worried about it.

question: Can you tell your mother?
answer: My mother? My mother and I don't connect. Don't you listen? I told you that.

question: No. Sorry's out. Come on, something's on your mind.
No, no, never mind the time. There's time. Look. Remember the contract? Control? Maybe there's some connection between control and uh...  what do we call it? - lack of feeling? Mmm?
When?
When?
Come on, come on, Jarrett, I thought you didn't like to fool around.
Like to play games, do you?
So?
I'll tell you what I want. I want you to leave "I don't know" out there on the table with the magazines. Okay?
answer: Yeah, and if I don't have an answer you want me to make one up?

question: Yeah. That would be nice. Make one up. Right now. About how there's no feelings in there.
Oh! Now you have, now you don't! Get it together, Jarrett.
answer: Why you hassle me? Why are you trying to make me mad?

question: Are you mad?
Oh, cut the shit! You're mad! You're mad as hell! You don't like being pushed. So why don't you do something about it!
Tell me to fuck off! I don't know.
answer: Well, fuck off! No. No, I can't, I can't do this.

question: Why not?
Why not?
answer: I can't do this. It takes too much energy to get mad!

question: Do you know how much energy it takes to hold it back?
answer: When I let myself feel low, I feel as lousy.

question: Oh! I beg your pardon! I never promised you a rose garden...
What?
Yeah?
That's it!
answer: Jesus, you're really weird! What about you? What do you feel, huh? Do you jack off or jerk off? Whatever you call it?

question: What do you think?
answer: What do I think? I think you married your fat lady... and you goona over fuck the daylights out of her!

question: Sounds good to me.
Oh, all right, all right.
answer: And be quiet. Be quiet. Be quiet. Conrad. Where are you?

question: Connie!
Calvin...
Calvin!
Calvin, give me the camera.
answer: No, I didn't get it yet , Beth.

question: Smile.
I think it can be saved.
answer: Have you talked to his teachers?

question: I don't think people want to be with him. He provokes people.
answer: Well. / Why don't you do this? / It's an awkward age.

question: Thank you.
answer: Maybe he needs a change. Are you sure he's eating enough?

question: Yes, Mother, of course.
answer: I think he'll be all right - if you're firm with him, mmm?

question: I think maybe he should go away to school. I just don't know how to deal with him any more.
I don't know. I suppose this doctor he's seeing.
answer: What sort of doctor... would make that decision for you?

question: A psychiatrist.
answer: I thought we were all finished with that.

question: No...
Berger.
I dunno, I suppose he's Jewish. Maybe just German.
answer: What does Cal say about all this?

question: Mmm mm mmm, Mmm mm mmm, Mmm mmm Mmm mm mmm. You are really a terrific tenor.
In fact. You should be doing the solo in that Russian thing.
No. I'm serious. You really sing well. I'm getting to know your voice.
Yeah!
answer: How can you hear me sing if you're singing?

question: Well... I don't always sing. Sometimes I just listen.
For instance, Marcia Blair can't sing a note.
Janet Fox only mouths the words and never sings.
Yeah... Do you like Vivaldi?
Telemann?
What kind of music do you like?
answer: Oh. Uh... Modern jazz. I like. Folk rock. Spoon on a glass.

question: Spoon on a ...glass?
answer: Mmmm. You make it look easy.

question: Really?
answer: Ah. You're just saying that? Alleluia! Ah ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha. Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, alleluia! Alleluia! Alleluia, Alleluia! Alleluia! Alleluia! Alleluia! Alleluia! Alleluia!

question: Ah. You're just saying that? Alleluia! Ah ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha. Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, alleluia! Alleluia! Alleluia, Alleluia! Alleluia! Alleluia! Alleluia! Alleluia! Alleluia!
Hello. Is Karen there?
It's a friend of hers from Hillsboro?
answer: Oh... Well, she's ...not home from school yet.

question: Oh. Um...Hmm. Just tell her I called. This is Conrad. Calling. Just tell her I called and I'm feeling great, and I just wanted to talk to her.
OK. Thank you.
All right
Hello. This is... Hello, this is Conrad calling. Jarrett?
Hi. Listen. I was... I was wondering if maybe you'd like...to go out sometime?
answer: You mean, with you? Like on a date?

question: Well, yeah, we wouldn't have to call it a real date. We could fake it sort of, to see how it goes..
answer: That was dumb. Forget it. Just forget it. Now start over.

question: Hi, this is Conrad Jarrett...
Quit? When? Where have you been every night?
Why didn't you tell us, Connie?
answer: I don't know, I didn't think it mattered.

question: It's really important to try to hurt me. Isn't it?
Oh? And how do I hurt you? By embarrassing you in front of a friend? Poor Beth! She has no idea what her son is up to! He lies and she believes every word of it.

You did! You lied everytime you came into this house at 6:30 ! If it's starting all over again, the lying, the covering up, the disappearing for hours, I will not stand for it! I can't stand it! I really can't!
answer: Well don't then! Go to Europe!

question: Well don't then! Go to Europe!
Cos the only reason she cares, the only reason she gives a fuck about it...
...is because someone else knew about it first!
Buck never would've been in the hospital!
I won't do it again. I really won't do it.
Ah! Oh, god, that's the pattern, isn't it? He walks all over us and then you go up and apologize to him.
answer: I am not going to apologize...

question: Yes of course you are! You always do! You've been apologizing to him ever since he got home from the hospital, only you don't see it!
answer: I am not apologizing. I'm trying to goddamn understand him!

question: Don't talk to me that way. Don't you talk to me the way he talks to you!
answer: Beth. Let's not fight. Okay? No fighting. Okay? Please. Let's go upstairs. I want to talk to you.

question: Beth. Let's not fight. Okay? No fighting. Okay? Please. Let's go upstairs. I want to talk to you.
In a minute...
answer: I didn't mean it. I didn't mean any of it. I am sorry. Please don't be mad.

question: I'm not mad ! I'm just trying to figure out what happened down there.
answer: I don't know what happened! I am sorry about it all. I am sorry about the whole thing. What I said, I didn't mean it. Just please tell her. Tell her I'm sorry, will you?

question: Why don't you tell her?
answer: Oh, God, no, I can't! Don't you see? I can't talk to her!

question: Why not?
answer: Ha! Because it doesn't change anything. It doesn't change the way she looks at me.

question: She was upset, Conrad. Your mother was hurt because you quit the swim team. I don't understand it myself.
answer: I don't mean just now. Don't you see? I don't mean just today.

question: What then? Explain it to me.
answer: Ha! I can't! Everything is German pudding with you , dad. You don't see things!

question: What things?
answer: That she hates me! Can't you see that?

question: Your mother doesn't hate you, Conrad?
answer: All right, all right. You're right. She doesn't. Please leave me alone, now.

question: What about this Dr. Berger? Do you think he's helping you?
answer: Don't blame it on Burger, it's not his fault!

question: Tuesday you felt great. You bought a Christmas tree, it was all hunky- dory. Okay?
Don't take refuge in one-liners like "You're the doctor". Okay? Because that pisses me off.
So everything was fine till you had the fight with your mother, then everything was lousy.
answer: Yeah, but I don't blame her. I mean, she's got... She's got her reasons. It's impossible after all the shit I've pulled!

question: What shit have you pulled? Hey! Remember! I'm talking proportion here. Now, what shit?
Uh, uh.
answer: Hey, come on, if you... Listen, I'm never gonna be forgiven for that. Never! You know, you can't get it out, you know, all the blood in her towels, in her rug. Everything had to be pitched. Even the tiles in the bathroom had to be regrouted. Christ, she fired the godamn maid because she couldn't dust the living room right. If you think I'm gonna forgive... - that she's gonna forgive me...

question: What?
answer: I think I just figured something out.

question: What?
answer: Who it is who can't forgive who...

question: Well a real problem... a real problem has a real solution.
Doesn't make it any less true.
Yeah, well... that's a hell of a secret you've been keeping on yourself.
answer: So what do I do now?

question: Recognize her limitations.
answer: You mean, like she can't love me?

question: Oh, kiddo, no. Like she can't love you enough. Like don't blame her for not loving you more than she's able.
answer: But she loves my father. I know she loved my brother. It's me!

question: Ha! Now we're back to the rotten kid routine! She can't love you because you're unlovable. Where does that leave your dad? How come he loves you? You're a rottenkid, doesn't he know that?
answer: That's different. He feels responsible. Besides, he loves everybody.

question: Ho, I get it! The guy's got no taste! He loves you, but he's wrong. Look... maybe she just can't express it the way you'd like her to. Maybe she's just afraid to show you what she feels.
I mean there's someone besides your mother you've got to forgive.
Why don't you give yourself a break? Let yourself off the hook?
We'll talk about it on Thursday.
Time's up.
answer: What do you mean? You're gonna pull the plug... Come on! What did I do?

question: Come on, Con. You know the rules.
answer: Rules? What rules? Can't I have a few minutes?

question: You think about it. Just think about it.
See you later. In the car, I was thinking

I know what happens here is only between you and him, and...I like that, I respect that. And...he's better, I can see that. I am not trying to put you down, I just don't believe in psychiatry as a panacea for everybody.
I wish I knew what the hell I was doing here.
answer: Well, you said you... thought you could shed some light on some things. What did you mean by that?

question: I don't know actually, I'm not sure, I think I meant in terms of Conrad. You see, I knew something was wrong even before he tried to... to kill himself. But I thought that... It's clear that he's very smart. He's been an "A" student ever since he started school, and naturally I thought that ...intelligent people could work out their own problems.
Yeah, sure I do. It's hard not to. It was luck. It was just luck that I happened to be there when he tried it. I could have been at a meeting. We both could've been away. It was luck!
answer: You think of yourself as a lucky man, then?

question: No! No. No. I used to. I used to think... that I was a lucky person... before... the "accident". Mmm, I guess the whole of life is nothing but an accident, is it? What happens to you. I should do with it.
answer: That sounds more like the philosophy of a drifter than a tax attorney.

question: Yeah. Maybe, maybe I am drifting a little. I can see myself, ...and I can see the two of them drifting away from me, and I just stand there watching.
answer: What would you want to do about that?

question: Something. I gotta do something about it. I don't know what.
answer: And you see them as on ...opposite sides of this fence?

question: Yeah... No. I don't know. I see her not being able to forgive him.

Oh, I don't know exactly. Being too much like her. People always think that she and Buck are... were ...were alike. But it's really she and Conrad. They were the only two that didn't cry at the funeral, you know? It's not easy for me to admit this but, uh... she didn't... His mother doesn't show him a great deal of affection. I'm not trying to put her down in any way at all. She is a wonderful woman, huh...
answer: Did she give Buck much affection to ...Buck?

question: Oh, god, yes, she loved Buck! Bucky got so much... I think what she felt for him was special. You know, he was her first-born. That's not unusual, is it?
Me? I loved Buck.
answer: What I mean is, your wife's affection.

question: For me you mean?

Mmm. She's very... No. There's no problem with her for me. We've been... We've been married nearly twenty one years. Everybody loves Beth. But, huh... for Conrad, - it's been difficult. He didn't talk about that? We don't know what happens here. It doesn't come up. I guess that's what it is. It's private here. Isn't it?
I think I know why I came here. I think I came here to talk about myself.
Hi!
What happened?
answer: Could we talk about Buck's funeral?

question: What?
answer: I know it'll seem trivial, but it's on my mind, or has been, and I'd just like to talk about it.

question: Why?
answer: When I was getting dressed for Buck's funeral, I was...

question: Calvin, what's the matter with you?
answer: Just let me get it off my chest,OK?

question: What could getting dressed for Buck's funeral possibly have to do with anything right now?
answer: I was wearing a blue shirt. And you said

question: Ha, ha.
answer: Just hear me out, Beth! It won't hurt you to listen!

question: I won't listen to that! No one in their right mind would listen to that.
answer: I just want to talk about something I always remembered.

question: Why do you want to remind me of it?
answer: Because I've always wondered, in some needling way, what it mattered what I wore. I was crazy that day. We were going to our son's funeral. And you were worried about what I wore on my feet. I'm sure it sounds like nothing to you, but it sticks with me and I just wanted to ...tell you about it.

question: It's all right.
answer: Beth! Beth! Hi! How are you?

question: Caroll! I'm fine. How are you?
I know. I'm so busy. I promise I'll call you soon and we'll have lunch.
How's Brad? Give him my love.
Isn't this madness? It gets worse every year!
What? Oh... No, no. No. Thanks. We've got Bennett's, and Grant's and Foley's. Ha, Conrad should get something for my mother and father. He's not supposed to get something for his doctor, is he?
answer: I don't think so. I think we should go see him, Beth. - Dr. Berger.

question: What?
answer: I think we could all go and see him together.

question: Why?
answer: He thinks it's a good idea.

question: Ho... He thinks it's a good idea? What does he know about me, about this family? I've never even met him.
answer: Exactly. That's the point. Wouldn't it be easier if we all talked about it? In the open.

question: About what? What are we gonna talk about? Don't try to change me, Calvin. I don't want anymore changes in my life. For God's sake, hasn't enough happened? Let's just hold on to what we've got!
answer: Darling, that is what this is for. Maybe you'll get a surprise.

question: I don't want any surprises. I know I'm not perfect. And if I can't go around hugging everybody all the time the way you do, then I'm sorry.
answer: I am not asking you to be perfect, you're missing the point.

question: I don't want to see any doctors or counselors. I am me. This is my family. And if we have problems, then we will solve those problems in the privacy of our own home, not by running to some kind of specialist everytime something goes wrong...
answer: Huh, no... Could you give me a couple of minutes, please?

question: ...running to experts every time something goes wrong.
answer: I do too. I want all of them to be nice Christmases

question: We need time together, Calvin. You and I. We have to get away. New Years'. We can spend some time in Houston with my brother and Audrey. You know, play a little golf. Relax.
I love you.
Conrad?
I don't bowl. I mean, I'm a horrible bowler.
Yeah. Well...
answer: Well, listen. We don't have to go bowling if you'd rather not, I'm not a bowling nut or anything. How funny are you?

question: On a scale from one to ten? ... About a ten.
answer: Hoo, that's pretty funny. Hey, well, listen, I promise you won't look silly.

question: Guarantee it?
Can you ever break the ball?
answer: Can't break the ball, can't break the floor, can't break anything in a bowling alley. And that's what I like about bowling alleys. Can't even break the record.

question: Hmm? What?
Catchy!
Mmm, mmm.
answer: I thought it'd get to you. I've been working on it all day.

question: Do you think people are punished for the things they do?
Yeah.
answer: Mmm, I don't believe in God.

question: Not at all?
answer: No. Well, it's not a question of degree. Either you do or you don't.

question: I believe in God.
answer: So you're afraid he'll punish you for something you did?

question: I've done a lot of things I'm ashamed of.
Did it hurt?
answer: No, I dunno, I don't remember really.

question: You don't want to talk about it?
answer: Ah, I don't know... I've never really talked about it. To doctors, but not to anyone else. You're the first who's asked.

question: Why did you do it?
answer: Uh... I don't know. It was like... falling into a hole. It was like falling into a hole, and it keeps getting bigger and bigger, .and you can't get out, and then, .all of a sudden, it's inside...and you're the hole, and you're trapped, and it's all over. Something like that. And it's not really scary, except it is when you think back on it. 'Cause you know what you were feeling stange and new...

question: What are you doing? Energetic. Those guys.
No...
answer: What? You thought they were funny?

question: No. I...
Anyway...
Are you okay?
answer: Yeah. Yeah, I'm fine. Uh... I'll give you a call.

question: Will you? I want you to.
Well... Guess I'll see you in choir.
Okay.
answer: I mean. Good night. Good night.

question: I am glad you can laugh about it, cos' it sure as hell wasn't funny. Come on, we weren't that bad.
answer: Let's face it, we stunk. I don't know how you can listen to that lecture on Buck Jarrett one more time. I know he is the world's greatest swimmer, but it bugs the hell outa me when he does that.

question: Stillman, cut it.
answer: Think he's ever gonna stop kissing the guy's picture?

question: Stillman, shut the hell up, would you? Hey, con, you want a ride?
We sure could've used you today, buddy.
answer: Oh, no, I don't think so.

question: You're the prick. Guys like you walk around like you're king shit. You give me a goddamn pain in the ass, you think we owe you...
answer: Come on! Connie. Come on! Cool it, Jarrett! Connie! Connie. That's enough.

question: Let go! Let go!
answer: It's all right! He's crazy! Just calm down, uh?

question: You're crazy! You're crazy! You know that? All right! Shit!
Here's your hat.
So you just make yourself look stupid when you let him get to you like that!
answer: So I look stupid, is that it?

question: No, it isn't. What is it with you? Huh? I don't know why you want to be in this alone? You know, I miss him too. Connie, the three of us were best friends!
answer: I can't help it, it hurts too much to be around you. I gotta go.

question: Get the sail down! Get it down!
answer: I can't hold it! Keep it starboard!

question: Get the sail down! Get it down!
answer: Keep it starboard! Go for it!

question: I am trying! I can't! Let it out! Let it out!
I can't!
Aaah! Bucky!
Here!
answer: We screwed up this time, Buddy! Dad's gonna haul ass over this!

question: It ain't so goddamned funny!
I won't, honest to God!
answer: Everything gonna be okay! Hang on. Brother!

question: Stay with me! Stay with me! Stay with me! Bucky! Where are you? Bucky! Bucky! Buck! Buck!
This is Conrad!
I need to see you!
I don't know!
I... I don't know!
answer: All right. Listen to me. Get to the office somehow, and I'll meet you there.

question: Okay.
Something happened...
I need... I need...
answer: Just wait till we get inside... Shit. You'd think they'd assume there'd be an emergency now and then?!

question: Something happened!
It's...
Oh. God! I need something.
answer: What do you need? Tell me!

question: It just keeps coming! I can't... I can't make it stop!
I gotta... I gotta... I gotta get off the hook for it. I gotta get off the hook!
For what I did!
What I did to him!
It's something... It's something... Don't you see? It's gotta be somebody's fault or there's no godamm point!
No, no... Oh, no. I don't mean that. It's that... It's just that... Buck, Bucky, I didn't mean it! Bucky, I didn't mean it! Bucky!
answer: I know that, it wasn't your fault.

question: But it was ...and I couldn't! I couldn't! It jammed! And then the halyard, the halyard jammed! I couldn't because the godamn halyard jammed! And then you're sittin' here, you're screwing around... ...until it's too late to do anything! And I'm supposed to take care of it! And I'm supposed to take care of it!
answer: And that wasn't fair, was it?

question: No! And then you say ... ..."Hang on!", and then you let go! Why'd you let go?
Yeah? Well. Screw you, you jerk!
answer: It hurts to be mad at him, doesn't it?

question: Yeah. He just wasn't careful. He just wouldn't care. He didn't see how a bad thing might happen.
answer: Bad things happen even when people are careful.

question: We were screwing around out there, we should've come in when it started to look bad.
answer: OK, so you made a mistake.

question: Why did he let go? Why?
answer: Maybe you were stronger. Did it ever occur to you that you might have been stronger?

question: Oh, God, I'd like to quit.
It's not easy. It's not that easy. God... I loved him.
Ka-ren. She killed herself! I just found out she's dead.
And she was fine, she was OK.
She was! She was! She told me! She said she was...
She was busy, she was feeling good and she...
I just wish I'd known...I could've done something.
answer: You saw her once and now you' want to take her on too?

question: No!
No. I just...
That isn't it. I... I feel bad about this, I feel really bad about this. And just let me feel bad about this!
answer: Okay. Listen. I feel bad about it too.

question: Why do things have to happen to people? It isn't fair.
You just do one wrong thing... and...
answer: Um-hmm. And what was the one wrong thing you did? You know.

question: Haaa...
I hung on. I stayed with the boat.
answer: Exactly. Now. You can live with that. Can't you?

question: I'm scared! I'm scared.
answer: Feelings are scary. And sometimes they're painful. And if you can't feel pain, then you're not gonna feel anything else either. You know what I'm saying?

question: I think so.
answer: You're here and you're alive. And don't tell me you don't feel that.

question: It doesn't feel good.
How do you know?
I don't know what I would've done...if you hadn't been here. You're really my friend?
Hi. I was gonna call but I didn't want to wake anyone.
Listen, I want to say something about the other night. I mean I liked being with you but I didn't like myself.
answer: Conrad. I was stupid. That was dumb of me to laugh and it was my fault. I just didn't know what to do. I was embarrassed.

question: Really? You were embarrassed?
answer: Yes. When those boys came in, it was awful and awkward. That's what I do when I get embarrassed. I laugh.

question: But they were all right. They were just up and they were having a good time, and I let them get in the way of what was happening. It was dumb. It was dumb. I've been doing lots of dumb things lately. I just didn't know wether or not you were being straight with me.
Yes?
Uh... Are you going to school?
No. I haven't.
Okay.
All right. How about that?
Oh, I do love that.
answer: Oh, these holes sure do love you. Oh boy, oh boy.

question: We should spend more time playing golf together, you know that? Maybe our next vacation, strictly golf. Pinehurst, Myrtle Beach...
answer: Pinehurst would be nice. I think Connie would like Pinehurst.

question: Do you do that deliberately or is it just a reflex?
answer: Well, you said "vacation", so I just assumed you meant him too.

question: I'm surprised you haven't felt the need to call him since we've been here.
answer: I was gonna call him tonight.

question: Six. Let's finish this.
What you started.
What you started.
answer: Ha! There's no point discussing it.

question: I think there is a point.
answer: He controls you even when you are two thousand miles away.

question: He isn't the problem.
No, he isn't. Let's talk about what's really bothering you.
answer: No, no. Let's talk about what's bothering you. Cos' that's what you want, isn't it?

question: Jesus, what have I done to make you so angry with me?
answer: It's not what you've done, it's what you think I've done. You blame me for the whole thing.

question: Can't you see anything except in terms of how it affects you?
answer: No! I can't! And neither can you, and neither can anybody else! Only maybe I'm just a little more honest about it!

question: Well, stop being so godamn honest, and start being a little generous! And start thinking about him for a while!
answer: I don't know what he expects from me. I never have known.

question: Well, I'll tell you what he expects!
answer: What? He wants me to throw my arms around him everytime he passes an exam? Well, I can't do it! I cannot respond when someone says

question: All he wants... All he wants is to know you don't hate him. That's it.
answer: Hate him? My God! How could I hate him? Mothers don't hate their sons! Is that what he told you? Do you see how you accept what he says with no questions, and you can't do the same thing to me, can you?

question: I just try to keep this family together...
answer: I don't know what everyone wants from me anymore!

question: I don't know what everyone wants from me anymore!
answer: Beth, listen. We all just want... Cal, Con, everybody, we just want you to be happy.

question: Happy?
I think I'm gonna turn in. Dinner was good. Really good.
Yeah. It was kind of a rough week.
answer: I hope your grandmother wasn't too tough on you?

question: Calvin?
What did you say?
answer: You are beautiful. And you are unpredictable. But you're so cautious. You're determined, Beth. But you know something? You're not strong. And I don't know if you're really giving. Beth is looking at him not knowing what this is about.

question: I feel the way I've always felt about you.
answer: We would've been all right, if there hadn't been any ...mess. But you can't handle mess. You need everything neat and ...easy. I don't know. Maybe you can't love anybody. It was so much Buck. And Buck died, it was as if you buried all your love with him, and I don't understand that. I just don't know.
